    Simulation - example usage

    simulation_description.Rmd

    We generate nn sequences s1,‚Ä¶,sns_1, \ldots, s_n of length NN based on real frequences of amino acids on full alphabet.

    exttt{A}

    We generate a set of mm motifs (m1,‚Ä¶,mmm_1, \ldots, m_m) with the following parameters:

    We inject motif by replacing a randomly selected part of a sequence with this motif. For example:

    We inject from 00 to kk motifs to a single sequence according to the following procedure:

    Let‚Äôs define a random variable XKX_K on a set of sequences s1,‚Ä¶,sns_1, \ldots, s_n which describes whether a sequence KK is a subsequence of sis_i. Namely, for any sequence sis_i:

    XK(si)={1,K‚äÜsi0,otherwiseX_K(s_i) = \left\{\begin{array}{rl} 1, & K \subseteq s_i\\ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{array} \right.

    where K‚äÜs2K \subseteq s_2 means that KK is a subsequence of s2s_2. For example

    Xùô∞ùô±(ùô∞ùô±ùô≤ùô≥)=1,X_{\texttt{AB}}(\texttt{ABCD}) = 1,Xùô∞_ùô±(ùô∞ùô±ùô≤ùô≥)=0.X_{\texttt{A\_B}}(\texttt{ABCD}) = 0.

    In this case we consider a standard logistic regression model where the joint effect of all motifs is the sum of their individual effects. Let w1,‚Ä¶,wmw_1, \ldots, w_m be weights related to motifs m1,‚Ä¶,mmm_1, \ldots, m_m. Let w0w_0 be an effect for the sequences without motifs. Then, we can define an additive logistic model as follows:

    g(EY)=w0+w1Xm1+w2Xm2+‚Ä¶+wmXmmg(EY) = w_0 + w_1 X_{m_1} + w_2 X_{m_2} + \ldots + w_m X_{m_m} We assume some particular values of w1,‚Ä¶,wmw_1, \ldots, w_m and calculate vector of probabilities pp as follows:

    p=g‚àí1(w0+w1Xm1+w2Xm2+‚Ä¶+wmXmm).p = g^{-1}(w_0 + w_1 X_{m_1} + w_2 X_{m_2} + \ldots + w_m X_{m_m}). Having pp we simulate yiy_i from binomial distribution B(1,pi)B(1, p_i).

    Another approach is based on interactions indicating that the effect of one predictor depends on the value of another predictor. Let‚Äôs define maximum number of motifs per sequence k=max{ki,i=1,‚Ä¶,n}k = \max\lbrace k_i, i = 1, \ldots, n\rbrace. Let w1,‚Ä¶,wkw_{1}, \ldots, w_{k} denote weights of single effects. Namely:

    g(EY)=w0+‚àëi=1kwiXmi+(‚àëi=1k‚àí1‚àëj=i+1kwijXmiXmj)+‚Ä¶+w1‚Ä¶kXm1‚Ä¶Xmkg(EY) = w_0 + \sum_{i = 1}^{k} w_{i} X_{m_i} + \left(\sum_{i = 1}^{k-1}\sum_{j = i + 1}^{k} w_{ij} X_{m_i}X_{m_j}\right) + \ldots + w_{1\ldots k} X_{m_1}\ldots X_{m_k}

    Here, we consider new variables, L1,‚Ä¶,LlL_1, \ldots, L_l where each of them is a logic expression based on a subset of motifs m1,‚Ä¶,mmm_1, \ldots, m_m. For example, L1(m1,m2,m3)=(Xm1‚àßXm2)‚à®Xm3.L_1(m_1, m_2, m_3) = (X_{m_1} \land X_{m_2}) \lor X_{m_3}. Each variable LiL_i obtains its own weight in the model. Our model is following:

    g(EY)=w0+‚àëi=1lwiLi.g(EY) = w_0 + \sum_{i = 1}^{l} w_i L_i.
